text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column text with two circular miniatures centrally inserted; each roundel is framed by a square border. Text blocks appear above and below each miniature. Wide outer margin on the right, narrow inner margin on the gutter side. Red rubric headings introduce each entry.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, executed with a professional book hand, extensive use of abbreviations and neat, consistent letterforms

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for roundel backgrounds, creating a luminous field. Ultramarine and verdigris provide contrast for frames and stylized mound. White lead highlights on feathers and ground add dimensionality. Red rubric both signals text divisions and complements blue borders in a balanced palette. Original pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening.

content_theme.scene_description: Primary Scene Analysis: In the upper roundel, two magpies face each other, perched symmetrically on a stylized green mound within a circular medallion. Their plumage is indicated by white and black paint layered over a burnished gold ground. The birds’ long, forked tails extend downward, their beaks nearly touching. The roundel is enclosed by a square frame segmented in alternating fields of azurite blue, vermilion red, and verdigris green with white filigree lines. The composition is flat but vivid, relying on color contrasts rather than depth. Secondary Elements: There are no marginal scenes; the two roundels function as discrete but related episodic images. Compositional Integration: The vertical stacking of identical medallion-and-frame units creates a cohesive visual rhythm. Scene Transitions: Shared color palette and identical framing devices link the magpie and pelican illustrations, directing the viewer’s eye downward. Visual-Textual Relationships: Each roundel immediately follows a red rubric heading (“De pica” and “De pellecanibus”), serving as a visual gloss to the entry. The text blocks contract above and below the roundels, yielding clear focal points. Caption-like red rubrics anchor the images to the animal descriptions, and the uniform framing emphasizes the hierarchy of entries in the bestiary.

notable_physical_characteristics: Layered pigment application with visible brush strokes

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This bestiary leaf, likely produced in a mid-13th-century French or English workshop, exemplifies the fusion of natural history observation with moral allegory characteristic of the medieval tradition. The use of burnished gold grounds within circular medallions framed by polychrome square borders aligns with Parisian illumination practices under Louis IX, while the dense Gothic textura quadrata script suggests production for a learned ecclesiastical clientele. The pairing of magpie and pelican entries underscores the didactic programme: the magpie’s chattering folly contrasts with the pelican’s Christological sacrifice. Technically, the application of white lead highlights over azurite and verdigris reveals advanced pigment layering and a confident underdrawing, while punchwork in the gesso underscores the luxury of the commission. Iconographically, the pelican’s self-wounding beard resonates with Eucharistic symbolism, reaffirming the text’s devotional utility. The uniform vertical stacking of miniatures reflects a standardized bestiary layout, facilitating quick visual reference. Comparison with the Rochester Bestiary (Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.16.2) shows a shared penchant for circular frames and moralizing captions. This page thus occupies a transitional moment between High Gothic naturalism and the more schematic illustrative modes of later medieval compendia, balancing visual appeal, instructional clarity, and spiritual resonance.
